{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3596149,"name":"","username":"singh321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/d9b06d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-19T07:05:44.064Z","cooked":"

Hi CD,
Our rookie team is trying to get our swerve drivebase up and running, and we need some help with planning our programming journey. Our hardware setup involves 4 donated WCP swerve X flipped corner mounts with 2 Falcon 500s per module, and we plan on purchasing the 4 CTRE CANcoders that go with them, as they seem the most widely used (the donating team kept theirs). We were wondering if we could replace them with the $30 ones at Thrifty Bot, but I have a feeling this is not a good idea. Has anyone managed to use the Thrifty bot encoders, or is sticking with the CTRE ones worth it? Since we’re a school-funded team, we can’t afford the $200 Pigoen IMU, so we plan on using our existing NavX 2 with our roboRio 2.0, meaning we will not have access to CTRE’s swerve code generator.

What would be the most beginner-friendly way to get our drivebase up and running with our current hardware setup? To start, I’m assuming Java is the way to go as it is documented extensively. Then we’ll set the CAN IDs of our hardware in tuner X and get our encoder offset values from there, along with knowing our gear ratios, chassis length. After this stage, should we use a swerve template on WPILib? Any recommendations on what challenges you might foresee us encountering, and how we should start programming? Also, is it best to have one programmer working on the code or multiple? We plan on sharing one Windows computer at school. Is this a common setup and something viable? Am I missing out on anything that I should know? Are there any resources out there that people would recommend for the basics?

Thanks a ton, we wanted to open up this avenue for help requests along the way, and for any experienced teams to share their advice. We wanted to make sure that our order for the CANcoders is followed by a smooth programming transition, as they are pretty expensive: $270. We may just be overcomplicating a bit…

Edit: What are the advantages and disadvantages between the TBT Encoder and CTRE Cancoder? (Both are absolute-magnetic encoders) So far, here is what we understand:

CANcoder:

  • Wired through a CAN
  • Configured in Tuner X
  • Designed for WCP Swerves

TBT Encoder:

  • Wired directly to Roborio
  • Mostly used with MK Modules from SDS

We used SDS MK4I modules and the YAGSL https://docs.yagsl.com/
library.
With YAGSL, the Thrifty is one of the choices of absolute encoder that can be made. The lower level code is invisible to the library user.

With CANCoders, the absolute offset can be stored in the CANCoder or in your code. With the Thrifty unit it is stored only in your code.

If you can post a link to your code, you can get further advice.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-04-19T11:30:40.279Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":30.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":499726,"topic_slug":"swerve-drive-101-getting-ready-for-programming","display_username":"icemannie","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.yagsl.com/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Welcome to Yet Another Swerve Document | YAGSL","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":74996,"username":"singh321","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/d9b06d/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28240,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/swerve-drive-101-getting-ready-for-programming/499726/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3596199,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-19T12:09:14.645Z","cooked":"

There are a bunch of online swerve code templates where really all you have to do to get them to work is just put in your swerve constants: encoder offsets, inversions for steer, drive, gear ratios…). WPILIB version works, I used the AdvantageKit TalonFX example project, doesn’t really matter. I would say to start simple to begin with, don’t try and get fancy and add your own features until you have a base that you know works (based on a template is best). Doubt your team will make this mistake like ours, but since you are using cancoders, glue the magnets (or else your offset will keep changing as the magnet moves around - don’t ask me how long it took me to figure that out on our robot). Since you are using a NavX, one suggestion that worked for us is to use USB as backup power to avoid disconnects while playing and having to reset the gyro (which you should definitely make a button for if you don’t already have one). Number of programmers depends on y’alls skill level, I would still definitely recommend you guys looking over each other’s code even if you don’t all collaborate on it. Sharing one computer can be fine, just going to be a bit of a pain - using github would probably alleviate any potential annoyances there. As for basics, I would recommend just reading the WPIlib docs to understand how swerve works and the libraries/methods function.

Ahhh, I see! I’m guessing you used the PWM cable to plug into the roboRio directly as the thrifty bot encoder can’t be integrated onto the CAN. It is definitely much cheaper I’ll run this option through our mentor as well, so we can pick between the CANcoder and the Thriftybot Encoder. I’ll have to confirm if the case is compatible for mounting on our modules but we can probably 3D print a custom one if needed. We’re currently making the choice between the two, and one factor is definitely the price.

Just out of curiosity, how’s the performance of the encoder? Is programming very similar regardless of which one you select? I’m aware that the CANcoder uses the Phoenix 6 library, and you can update it and whatnot in tuner X, but not so sure about the Thrifty Bot one. Thanks for your input!

Screenshot 2025-04-19 at 8.27.18 PM1220×1266 213 KB

You should look into the advantage kit swerve template ( TalonFX Swerve Template | AdvantageKit ) made by Team 6328 comes complete with setup instructions and NAVX code ( as well as simulation etc ). You will have to make the change to use the provided navx code though but it should work without any problems. I highly recommend the CANCoders .
